title: The Smoky Mountains' highest peak returns to Native American name - Democratic Underground Forums
text: [Create a free account](/?com=login&create=1)Support DU (and get rid of ads!): [Become a Star Member](/star) [Latest Breaking News](/?com=forum&id=1014) [Editorials & Other Articles](/?com=forum&id=1016) [General Discussion](/?com=forum&id=1002) [The DU Lounge](/?com=forum&id=1018) [All Forums](/?com=forums) [Issue Forums](/?com=forum&id=1311) [Culture Forums](/?com=forum&id=1312) [Alliance Forums](/?com=forum&id=1313) [Region Forums](/?com=forum&id=1314) [Support Forums](/?com=forum&id=1315) [Help & Search](/?com=search) Related: [General Discussion](/?com=forum&id=1002) [Editorials & Other Articles](/?com=forum&id=1016), [Issue Forums](/?com=forum&id=1311), [Alliance Forums](/?com=forum&id=1313), [Region Forums](/?com=forum&id=1314) (112,773 posts) Thu Sep 19, 2024, 03:19 PM 1 hr ago [Yo_Mama_Been_Loggin](/?com=profile&uid=124071) The highest peak at Great Smoky Mountains National Park is officially reverting to its Cherokee name more than 150 years after a surveyor named it for a Confederate general. The US Board of Geographic Names voted on Wednesday in favor of a request from the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians to officially change the name Clingmans Dome to Kuwohi, according to a news release from the park. The Cherokee name for the mountain translates to mulberry place. The Great Smoky National Park team was proud to support this effort to officially restore the mountain and to recognize its importance to the Cherokee People, Superintendent Cassius Cash said in the release. The Cherokee People have had strong connections to Kuwohi and the surrounding area, long before the land became a national park. The National Park Service looks forward to continuing to work with the Cherokee People to share their story and preserve this landscape together. https://www.yahoo.com/news/smoky-mountains-highest-peak-returns-022638709.html [InfoView thread info, including edit history](/?com=thread&info=1&address=100219481651) [TrashPut this thread in your Trash Can (My DU » Trash Can)](/?com=login) [BookmarkAdd this thread to your Bookmarks (My DU » Bookmarks)](/?com=login)14 replies, 916 views [ShareGet links to this post and/or share on social media] [AlertAlert this post for a rule violation](/?com=login) [PowersThere are no powers you can use on this post] [EditCannot edit other people's posts] [ReplyReply to this post](/?com=post&post&forum=1002&pid=19481651) [EditCannot edit other people's posts] [Rec (56)] [ReplyReply to this post](/?com=post&forum=1002&pid=19481651) [NoneDon't highlight anything](#!) [5 newestHighlight 5 most recent replies](#!) [I love this](#post1)Traildogbob 1 hr ago #1 [Surrounding county law enforcement only sat at the boundary for a few days....](#post14)mtngirl47 6 min ago #14 [Fine with me.](#post2)maxsolomon 52 min ago #2 [I was just going to say that nt](#post4)leftieNanner 40 min ago #4 [At least Rainier is a pretty name.](#post5)LisaM 32 min ago #5 [Sounds like something you should see a gastroenterologist for.](#post12)progressoid 8 min ago #12 [It's a great place, on a cloudy day you can see about six inches in front of you. On a clear day, forever, sort of.](#post3)twodogsbarking 44 min ago #3 [Cool](#post6)Joinfortmill 23 min ago #6 [This makes me happy](#post7)Coexist 23 min ago #7 [Good news, I like it](#post8)birdographer 14 min ago #8 [Good News .](#post9)Botany 11 min ago #9 [I am going to look up and report back -](#post10)cilla4progress 10 min ago #10 [more please nt](#post11)et tu 9 min ago #11 [To be factually transparent](#post13)misanthrope 7 min ago #13 (9,628 posts) [Traildogbob](/?com=profile&uid=350607) Nice visitor center and spiraling overlook up top And worth a look if you go there. Lots and lots of dead Firs and hemlocks from insects, but the 360 view far away is amazing. Too touristy for me, we took Dendrology students there every year for high elevation tree ID. But if youre close, well worth a look. And Cherokee just legalized rec weed. But I would not attempt to buy and do takeout. The surrounding counties will not play, and these police are hard core MAGAs. Waiting at the tribal boundaries for hippies. (1,045 posts) [mtngirl47](/?com=profile&uid=298389) [Traildogbob (Reply #1)](#post1) Locals and business people in surrounding counties have been calling the Sheriffs to get them to back off---stop and search will only hurt tourism which is basically our only industry. I live just one mile outside of Cherokee and I have not seen a step up by law enforcement since the first few days of them opening the dispensary. Everyone I know just drives to the dispensary, purchases what they want and then drive home with no problems. Cherokee does have to fly their product via helicopter from their land where they are growing it to the boundary, because the Swain County Sheriff threatened to stop the transport. On a political note----our current Congressman, Chuck Edwards (R), came out strongly against Cherokee selling cannibis, going as far as to suggest he would introduce laws taking away Tribal sovereignty and funding. The Democratic candidate, Caleb Rudow is working hard to get the Cherokee people's vote. (34,515 posts) [maxsolomon](/?com=profile&uid=105187) "Clingman's Dome" always sounded gross. Now change Mt. Rainier back to Tahoma. (15,535 posts) [leftieNanner](/?com=profile&uid=266513) (28,294 posts) [LisaM](/?com=profile&uid=103353) I kind of like when places are known by both names, unless there is some compelling reason to change it to just one name (which in this case, it sounds as if there was, another example being Squaw Peak). A lot of places traditionally have multiple names. I have no issue with that. (50,416 posts) [progressoid](/?com=profile&uid=156375) (11,666 posts) [twodogsbarking](/?com=profile&uid=359361) (15,785 posts) [Joinfortmill](/?com=profile&uid=352829) (25,347 posts) [Coexist](/?com=profile&uid=159643) (2,185 posts) [birdographer](/?com=profile&uid=346559) But holy cow, the pamphlets and brochures and other printed material will all require editing before reprinting! Anyone know how to pronounce that name? (71,799 posts) [Botany](/?com=profile&uid=159729) The original Americans need to be honored and respected. Kuwohi is a beautiful name. (25,439 posts) [cilla4progress](/?com=profile&uid=157590) how to pronounce it! Kuwohi (pronounced koo-WHOA-hee) is the Cherokee name for the mountain and translates to "mulberry place". The Cherokee syllabary for it is ᎫᏬᎯ.22 hours ago (1,701 posts) [et tu](/?com=profile&uid=370737) (7,914 posts) [misanthrope](/?com=profile&uid=125515) When it was named for Thomas Clingman, the Confederate States of America didn't exist. Clingman was a lawyer, former U.S. House member and was serving in the U.S. Senate at the time. He gave that up to join the forces of the CSA in 1861. That said, his eventual siding with seditionists is enough to have his name removed. That the mountain's name was changed to reflect the native culture of the area, much like Denali in Alaska, is fitting.
